articles.headline: Amazon Deforestation, Once Tamed, Comes Roaring Back
articles.snippet: A decade after the “Save the Rainforest” movement captured the world’s imagination, Cargill and other food giants are pushing deeper into the wilderness.
articles.abstract: A decade after the “Save the Rainforest” movement captured the world’s imagination, Cargill and other food giants are pushing deeper into the wilderness.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLONIA BERLIN, Bolivia — A few months ago, a representative from Cargill traveled to this remote colony in Bolivia’s eastern lowlands in the southernmost reaches of the vast Amazon River basin with an enticing offer.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi, Claire Rigby and Jeremy White

articles.headline: Did Someone Say ‘Tax Code Rewrite’? Lobbyists Scramble
articles.snippet: The Washington “swamp” President Trump likes to denounce is still teeming with life — and it is converging on lawmakers drafting tax legislation.
articles.abstract: The Washington “swamp” President Trump likes to denounce is still teeming with life — and it is converging on lawmakers drafting tax legislation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The homebuilders lobby fears that an ambitious rewrite of the entire tax code will stifle the housing market. Retailers fret that it will make the cost of their imports soar. For charities and their representatives, the worry is that donations will be stunted, plaguing nonprofit groups that serve the neediest Americans.

articles.headline: Trump Intensifies His Attacks on Journalists and Condemns F.B.I. ‘Leakers’
articles.snippet: Reporters from The Times and other outlets were not allowed to enter the office of the press secretary, Sean Spicer, in an unusual breach of protocol.
articles.abstract: Reporters from The Times and other outlets were not allowed to enter the office of the press secretary, Sean Spicer, in an unusual breach of protocol.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump turned the power of the White House against the news media on Friday, escalating his attacks on journalists as “the enemy of the people” and berating members of his own F.B.I. as “leakers” who he said were putting the nation at risk.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Andy Weir’s Best Seller ‘The Martian’ Gets a Classroom-Friendly Makeover
articles.snippet: Science teachers are using a new edition of “The Martian” to teach physics, astronomy and chemistry. It’s the same story — minus the profanity.
articles.abstract: Science teachers are using a new edition of “The Martian” to teach physics, astronomy and chemistry. It’s the same story — minus the profanity.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are more than 160 swear words in Andy Weir’s sci-fi thriller, “The Martian,” including two memorably deployed F-words in the novel’s first three sentences.

articles.headline: Score One for the Bank Whistle-Blowers
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court asked a lower court to reconsider a case in which former bank employees accused their employers of misusing federal bailout funds.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court asked a lower court to reconsider a case in which former bank employees accused their employers of misusing federal bailout funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here is something to celebrate: The United States Supreme Court just handed whistle-blowers one of their bigger wins in a long time.

articles.headline: A Lawsuit Against Uber Highlights the Rush to Conquer Driverless Cars
articles.snippet: The suit, brought by the autonomous car business Waymo, accuses Uber and a star engineer, Anthony Levandowski, of planning to steal trade secrets.
articles.abstract: The suit, brought by the autonomous car business Waymo, accuses Uber and a star engineer, Anthony Levandowski, of planning to steal trade secrets.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Late last year, Uber, in defiance of California state regulators, went ahead with a self-driving car experiment on the streets of San Francisco under the leadership of Anthony Levandowski, a new company executive.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: The Anti-Trump Activist Taking On Retailers
articles.snippet: Putting together a list of companies selling Trump products has transformed Shannon Coulter’s life, and not always for the better.
articles.abstract: Putting together a list of companies selling Trump products has transformed Shannon Coulter’s life, and not always for the better.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Sitting in a basement office that she rents by the hour, Shannon Coulter ticks off the activities she gave up in defiance of President Donald J. Trump: renting movies with her husband on Amazon, and shopping at Nordstrom, Macy’s and other retailers that sell Ivanka Trump’s products.

articles.headline: For Marketers, TV Sets Are an Invaluable Pair of Eyes
articles.snippet: Several companies, eager to help brands more efficiently spend advertising money, use devices to track viewing habits in surprisingly granular detail.
articles.abstract: Several companies, eager to help brands more efficiently spend advertising money, use devices to track viewing habits in surprisingly granular detail.
articles.lead_paragraph: While Ellen Milz and her family were watching the Olympics last summer, their TV was watching them.

articles.headline: U.S. Wary of Its New Neighbor in Djibouti: A Chinese Naval Base
articles.snippet: With tensions between the rivals increasing, American strategists worry that operations at the Pentagon’s Camp Lemonnier will be observed once China completes its military port.
articles.abstract: With tensions between the rivals increasing, American strategists worry that operations at the Pentagon’s Camp Lemonnier will be observed once China completes its military port.
articles.lead_paragraph: DJIBOUTI — The two countries keep dozens of intercontinental nuclear missiles pointed at each other’s cities. Their frigates and fighter jets occasionally face off in the contested waters of the South China Sea.
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Immigration Agents Discover New Freedom to Deport Under Trump
articles.snippet: The president’s plan to arrest and deport vast numbers of undocumented immigrants will be carried out by agents who say they feel unshackled.
articles.abstract: The president’s plan to arrest and deport vast numbers of undocumented immigrants will be carried out by agents who say they feel unshackled.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Virginia, Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents waited outside a church shelter where undocumented immigrants had gone to stay warm. In Texas and in Colorado, agents went into courthouses, looking for foreigners who had arrived for hearings on other matters.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish, Caitlin Dickerson and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: Trump Ruled the Tabloid Media. Washington Is a Different Story.
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump was no stranger back in the day to the art of news management. But even that did not seem to prepare him for the capital press corps.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump was no stranger back in the day to the art of news management. But even that did not seem to prepare him for the capital press corps.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House press secretary, Sean Spicer, has taken to slapping journalists who write unflattering stories with an epithet he sees as the epitome of low-road, New York Post-style gossip: “Page Six reporter.”
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: For Commerce Pick Wilbur Ross, ‘Inherently Bad’ Deals Paid Off
articles.snippet: Mr. Ross, who amassed a fortune with help from trade deals like Nafta, has vowed to tear up those deals if confirmed as commerce secretary.
articles.abstract: Mr. Ross, who amassed a fortune with help from trade deals like Nafta, has vowed to tear up those deals if confirmed as commerce secretary.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — With a panel of senators questioning him, the billionaire investor Wilbur L. Ross stayed on message: If confirmed as President Trump’s commerce secretary, he would protect American workers and tear up bad trade deals that harmed American industry.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Elisabeth Malkin

articles.headline: In Global Expansion, Netflix Makes Friends With Carriers
articles.snippet: The online streaming service is building relationships with cable and cellphone operators worldwide in its bid to expand internationally.
articles.abstract: The online streaming service is building relationships with cable and cellphone operators worldwide in its bid to expand internationally.
articles.lead_paragraph: As he sat in his office in central Paris, Christian Bombrun, an executive at Orange, the French cellphone and cable operator, got an unexpected call. It was Netflix, the American streaming giant, proposing a deal.

articles.headline: Coal Industry Casts Itself as a Clean Energy Player
articles.snippet: Companies are joining with environmental groups to lobby for expanded subsidies to encourage technologies to reduce carbon emissions from coal plants.
articles.abstract: Companies are joining with environmental groups to lobby for expanded subsidies to encourage technologies to reduce carbon emissions from coal plants.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump has questioned the science behind climate change as “a hoax” in positioning himself as a champion of coal. The three largest American coal producers are taking a different tack.

articles.headline: Trump Embraces ‘Enemy of the People,’ a Phrase With a Fraught History
articles.snippet: It is unclear if the president is aware of the historic resonance of the label, but his use of it has left some historians scratching their heads.
articles.abstract: It is unclear if the president is aware of the historic resonance of the label, but his use of it has left some historians scratching their heads.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The phrase was too toxic even for Nikita Khrushchev, a war-hardened veteran communist not known for squeamishness. As leader of the Soviet Union, he demanded an end to the use of the term “enemy of the people” because “it eliminated the possibility of any kind of ideological fight.”

articles.headline: In Trump-CNN Battle, 2 Presidents Who Love a Spectacle
articles.snippet: Jeffrey A. Zucker, the president of CNN, who once had a close rapport with President Trump, is shrugging off the White House’s vitriol toward his network.
articles.abstract: Jeffrey A. Zucker, the president of CNN, who once had a close rapport with President Trump, is shrugging off the White House’s vitriol toward his network.
articles.lead_paragraph: He is a favorite target of President Trump’s ire, the leader of a television network that the White House routinely accuses of peddling “fake news,” and a contentious figure in his own right whose showcasing of Mr. Trump in the presidential campaign led to howls from the political establishment.

articles.headline: To Keep U.S. Jobs, Chip Makers Share a Factory and Pin Hopes on Trump
articles.snippet: Computer chips are still made in the United States, but foreign competition is looming. The industry wants President Trump to help.
articles.abstract: Computer chips are still made in the United States, but foreign competition is looming. The industry wants President Trump to help.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEHI, Utah — Nestled at the foot of the Wasatch Mountains here, the IM Flash plant is a paragon of American high-tech manufacturing.

articles.headline: Trump to Ask for Sharp Increases in Military Spending, Officials Say
articles.snippet: President Trump will instruct federal agencies on Monday to assemble a budget that would also make major cuts to agencies like the E.P.A. but not reduce funding for the largest entitlement programs.
articles.abstract: President Trump will instruct federal agencies on Monday to assemble a budget that would also make major cuts to agencies like the E.P.A. but not reduce funding for the largest entitlement programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump will instruct federal agencies on Monday to assemble a budget for the coming fiscal year that includes sharp increases in Defense Department spending and drastic enough cuts to domestic agencies that he can keep his promise to leave Social Security and Medicare alone, according to four senior administration officials.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush, Kate Kelly and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Assailing the White House From Hollywood’s Glass House
articles.snippet: Who do our stars think they’re winning over with political oratory side-by-side with a bacchanalia of self-congratulation?
articles.abstract: Who do our stars think they’re winning over with political oratory side-by-side with a bacchanalia of self-congratulation?
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — And the award for best political stemwinder goes to …

articles.headline: He’s a Local Pillar in a Trump Town. Now He Could Be Deported.
articles.snippet: Residents have only good things to say about Juan Carlos Hernandez Pacheco, but his arrest by immigration agents has left his Illinois town in a muddle.
articles.abstract: Residents have only good things to say about Juan Carlos Hernandez Pacheco, but his arrest by immigration agents has left his Illinois town in a muddle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST FRANKFORT, Ill. — Ask residents of this coal-mining crossroads about President Trump’s decision to crack down on undocumented immigrants and most offer no protest. Mr. Trump, who easily won this mostly white southern Illinois county, is doing what he promised, they say. As Terry Chambers, a barber on Main Street, put it, the president simply wants “to get rid of the bad eggs.”

articles.headline: Buffett Asks Big Money: Why Pay High Fees?
articles.snippet: A staunch defender of index funds, Warren Buffett used his annual shareholders’ letter to skewer money managers who charge more for inferior results.
articles.abstract: A staunch defender of index funds, Warren Buffett used his annual shareholders’ letter to skewer money managers who charge more for inferior results.
articles.lead_paragraph: Poof: $100 billion disappeared.
